article:
The race to become Britain’s next PM
Rivals to succeed Theresa May are jockeying for position

race to succeed Theresa May as leader of the Conservative Party, and thus prime minister, has been going on ever since her disastrous election performance two years ago. On May 16th it moved up a gear when senior Tory backbenchers met Mrs May and extracted a promise that if, as expected, she fails in her fourth attempt to pass her Brexit bill in the House of Commons early next month, she will outline a timetable for her departure. The upshot is that 10 Downing Street is likely to have a new occupant this summer.

The man most fancied to succeed her, Boris Johnson, a former foreign secretary and prominent Brexiteer, had earlier that day thrown his hat in the ring. “Of course I’m going for it,” he told an audience of insurance brokers in Manchester. Expect more candidates to break cover over the course of the next few weeks.

Betfair Exchange, a gambling website, has been tracking punters’ predictions on the next Tory leader. According to the wisdom of the crowd, a handful of candidates stand out.

Source: Betfair Exchange

Adrian Wooldridge, our political editor, assesses the chances of the leading Conservative politicians hoping to take the top job in this short film
title: The race to become Britain’s next PM
